children.name: say what the price or value of st is
put a price
children.definition: /value/figure onsthđịnh giácho st
examples: to say what you think the price or value of something is
_The agent has put a price of £120 000 on our house.
_You can't put a value on friendship (= say what it is worth) .

children.name: to calculate an amount or price
calculate
children.definition: /ˈkælkjɑleɪt/  to find out how much something will cost, how long something will take etc by using numbers:
examples: tính ( hết bao nhiêu tiền, thời gian....)
▪ Their accountant calculated the total cost of the project.
calculate how much/how many/how far etc: tính bao nhiêu/bao xa
▪ I began calculating how long it would take to get to the airport if I left at 4:00.
calculate that : tính rằng
▪ Sally calculated that she needed $300 to pay all her bills.
calculation/ˌkælkjɑˈleɪʃən/ [countable noun] a process by which you calculate a total, price, time etc:
▪ NASA calculations put the cost of the space program at $118 billion.

children.name: work out
children.definition: alsofigureoutAmerican /ˌwɜːʳk ˈaʊt, ˌfɪgər ˈaʊtǁˌfɪgjər-/  especiallyspokento calculate an answer, amount, price, or value:
examples: tính ra ( một cau hỏi, số lượng, giá cả, giá trị )
work/figure out something: tính ra/tìm ra cái gì
▪ I always use a calculator to work out percentages.
▪ Has anyone been able to figure out the answer to number seven?
work/figure something out: tìm ra/tính ra cái gì
▪ ‘How much do I owe you?’ ‘I haven’t worked it out yet.’
work out how much/how many/how far etc: Tính ra bao nhiêu / bao xa
▪ We need to work out how much food we’ll need to take with us.
▪ I spent all of last night trying to figure out how much this wedding is going to cost me.

children.name: estimate
children.definition: /ˈestɪmeɪt, ˈestəmeɪt/  to guess an amount, price, or number as exactly as you can:
examples: dự tính, ước đoán
▪ Analysts estimate the business earned about $135 million last year.Những nhà phân tích ước tính loại kinh doanh này kiếm ra 135 triệu đô năm ngoái
estimate that: tính toán/dự tính/ước đoán là
▪ The police department estimates that the number of violent crimes will increase this year by about 15%.Viện cảnh sát ước tính rằng số lượng tội phạm năm nay sẽ tăng khoảng 15%
estimate something to be something: ước tính cái gì thành bao nhiêu
▪ At that point, the public sector deficit was estimated to be around £45 billion.:Vào lúc đó, mức thâm hụt của phần công được thước thành khoảng 45 tỷ bảng anh
estimate something at something: ước tính cái gì ở mức bao nhiêu
▪ Industry sources estimate the value of the ranch at $7 million.Các tài nguyên nghành công nghiệp ước tính ở mức 7 triệu đô.
estimate how much/how many/how far etc: ước tính bao nhiêu/bao xa
▪ Our staff will help you estimate how much fabric you will requireNhân viên của chúng tôi sẽ giúp đỡ trong việc tính toán phải mất bao nhiêu vải cho nhu cầu của bạn.

children.name: make
children.definition: /meɪk/  Britishinformalto calculate a particular total :
examples: make it 250/20 kilos/$50 etc: tính bao nhiêu
▪ ‘How much do I owe you for the meal?’ ‘I make it $10.50.’
▪ Will you count these figures again? I make the total 248, but Chris made it 249.

children.name: figure
children.definition: /ˈfɪgəʳǁˈfɪgjər/  American to calculate an amount :
examples: tính ra/tìm ra
▪ He needs to sit down and figure out how many people are coming.
▪ There has been criticism about the current method for figuring social security retirement benefits.

children.name: assess
children.definition: /əˈses/  to calculate what thevalueorcostof something is, especially beforebuyingit orsellingit :
examples: ▪ This computer program will assess how much is spent on each student within the school.
▪ I took the ring to a jeweller to have its value assessed.
assess something at something :
▪ The total value of the paintings is assessed at $20 million.

children.name: to take or ask for an amount of money in return for st you are selling
charge
children.definition: /tʃɑːʳdʒ/  if someone charges an amount of money for a service or product, that is how much you pay for it:
examples: tính giá, đòi trả
▪ Lawyers charge such high fees, but they never seem short of clients.
charge £5/$60 etc for
▪ My piano teacher charges £9 for a half hour class.
▪ Small shops charge much higher prices for the same products.
charge somebody £5/$60 etc
▪ The cheapest doctor we could find charged us four hundred francs for a five minute examination.

children.name: want £20 for
children.definition: want £20/$40 etc for/wɒnt ˌtwenti ˈpaʊndz ◂20, etc fɔːʳ ‖wɑːnt-/ informalto ask for or expect to be paid a particular amount of money for something that you are selling to another person:
examples: ▪ I might be interested in your TV. How much do you want for it?
▪ Bob said he’d give Frank private guitar lessons, but he wanted $60 an hour.

children.name: offer
children.definition: /ˈɒfəʳǁˈɔː-, ˈɑː-/  to say that you will pay someone a particular amount of money in exchange for something:
examples: offer somebody something
▪ Chaldon was offered a huge salary to become team manager.
offer (somebody) something for something
▪ Police are offering a reward for information about the shooting.
▪ Some guy offered me £2,000 for the car. I just laughed and hung up the phone.

children.name: bid
children.definition: /bɪd/  an offer to pay a particular amount of money for something, when other people are also offering different amounts of money, and hoping to buy it:
examples: giá được đưa ra để mua cái gì (nhất là tại cuộc bán đấu giá)
bid for
▪ The highest bid for the painting was £400.
put in/submit/make a bidsay how much you will pay
▪ A number of companies have submitted bids to buy the supermarket chain.

children.name: give
children.definition: /gɪv/informalto pay a particular amount of money for something, especially when you arebuyingitfrom another person, so that the price isnotfixed:
examples: trả giá
▪ ‘I don’t really want to spend that much.’ ‘OK, how much are you prepared to give?’
give for
▪ Did they give you the asking price for the house?
give (somebody) £5/$10 etc
▪ He said he’d give £40 for the painting, so I said yes.

children.name: make an offer
children.definition: to offer a particular amount of money in order to buy a house, car etc:
examples: trả giá
make an offer for/on
▪ Has anyone made an offer yet for the house?
make an offer of
▪ Immediately after they were shown the property, they made an offer of $165,000.
make somebody a generous offer
▪ I’m prepared to make you a very generous offer.

children.name: bid
children.definition: /bɪd/  to offer to pay a particular amount of money for something you want to buy, in competition with other people:
examples: bid $10/£20 etc for something
▪ At the auction, I bid £50 for a small antique mirror, but it ended up selling for over £200.
▪ Baxley International said on Friday that it bid $11 million in cash and stock to acquire the Los Angeles-based company.
bid for something
▪ Competition between the two companies bidding for the contract is fierce.
bid against somebody
▪ San Diego is asking private companies to bid against city workers to run one of the city’s three water treatment plants.
bidder [countable noun]
▪ The equipment will be auctioned off to the highest bidder the person who bids the highest amount.

children.name: guess what the price or value of sth is
put sth at sth
children.definition: putsthatsthphrasal verb định giábao nhieu
examples: toguessor roughly calculate that something will cost a particular amount, or thatsomething is a particular size, number or amount
_The value of the painting has been put at £1 million.
_I'd put her at (= guess that her age is) about 35.

children.name: value / appraise
children.definition: valueverbMONEY định giá
examples: UK(USappraise) to give a judgment about how much money something might be sold for
_He valued the paintingat$2000.
_The insurance company said I should have my jewellery valued.
revalueverb[ T ]địnhlạigiá
to change the value of something or to consider it again
_to revalue a currency
_The company's assets are periodically revalued.
valuationnoun[ C or U ] sự định giá
the act of deciding how much money something
might be sold for or the amount of money decided on
_You can receive a home loan of up to 95% of the official valuation of the property.

children.name: to calculate how much st costs
cost
children.definition: /kɒstǁkɔːst/  to calculate the total cost of a plan or process - used especially in business contexts:
examples: be costed
▪ The project had been incorrectly costed and the money ran out before it could be completed.
get/have something costed
▪ It would be a good idea to get the plan costed before presenting it to the board.

children.name: price
children.definition: /praɪs/  to decide how much a product should cost:
examples: định giá
be priced
▪ Porsche said its new 911 Carrera 4s would be very competitively priced.
▪ Please get your fruit and vegetables weighed and priced before you take them to the checkout.

children.name: estimate
children.definition: /ˈestɪmət, ˈestəmət/  a statement that says how much money it will probably cost to build or repair something:
examples: Giá ước tính
▪ The final cost was £2000 higher than the original estimate.
estimate for
▪ I’ve asked the builders to give us an estimate for fixing the roof.

children.name: to decide what the value of sth is
value
children.definition: British/appraiseAmerican /ˈvæljuː, əˈpreɪz/  to decide what thevalueof something is, especially when it is your job to do this:
examples: định giá ( như một công việc )
▪ He works for an antique firm, valuing furniture.
▪ The apartment was appraised, and Stephen gave Julie a check for half the amount.
value/appraise something at $100/$500 etc
▪ The builder valued the work already done at $400.
have something valued/appraised
get a professional person to value it for you
▪ Those silver bowls could be worth a lot of money -- you ought to have them appraised.

children.name: valuation
children.definition: /ˌvæljuˈeɪʃən/ British /appraisal American
examples: ▪ I took the ring to a shop for valuation.

children.name: sb who's job is estimating price
valuer /appraiser
children.definition: valuerBritish/appraiserAmerican
examples: ▪ The valuer person whose job is to value things said the plate was worth £500.

children.name: quantity surveyor
children.definition: nounUK ngườiđịnh giá (công trình xâydựng)
examples: a person whose job is to calculate the cost of the
materials and work needed for futurebuilding work

children.name: quote
children.definition: verbGIVE PRICE định giá;đặt giá
examples: [ T ] to give a price, especially one that will be charged for doing a piece of work
_The architect has quoted £40,000 to build an extension.

children.name: price
children.definition: verb tìm hiểugiá
examples: [ T ] to discover how much something costs
_We went around all the travel agents pricing the different tours.

children.name: miscalculate
children.definition: /ˌmɪsˈkælkjɑleɪt/
examples: tính nhầm
▪ We have too many chairs. I must have miscalculated.
Chúng ta có quá nhiều ghế, hẳn là tôi đã tính sai
▪ The city miscalculated the cost of earthquake repairs for the Bay Bridge.
Thành phố đã tính toán sai về chí phí sửa chữa sau động đất của cầu Bay
miscalculate how much/how many/how long etc:
tính nhầm bao nhiêu, bao lâu
▪ Sorry we’re late -- we miscalculated how long it would take to get here.
Xin lỗi chúng tôi đến trễ - chúng tôi đã tính nhầm về khoảng thời gian đến đây

children.name: overestimate
children.definition: /ˌəʊvərˈestɪmeɪt, ˌəʊvərˈestəmeɪt/  to wronglyguessprice or number by making the total too high:
examples: tính quá cao, định giá quá cao
▪ A Harvard University survey found that Americans significantly overestimate the cost of higher education.

children.name: underestimate
children.definition: /ˌʌndərˈestɪmeɪt, ˌʌndərˈestəmeɪt/  to wrongly guess an price by making it too low:
examples: tính qua thấp, định giá quá thấp
▪ We saved about $1000 for our trip but we underestimated and may have to wait until next year to go.

children.name: costing
children.definition: noun dự toángiá ( trong tương lai )
examples: (a) calculation of the future cost of something such as a possible product
_We'll need accurate costings before we can agree to fund the scheme.

children.name: cap
children.definition: verb-pp-LIMIT
examples: [ T often passive ]to put a limit on the amount of money that can be charged or spentin connection with a particular activity
_High spending councils have all been (rate/charge) capped.
_Our mortgage is capped at 8.75% for five years.

children.name: to persuade sb to reduce the price of sth
haggle
children.definition: /ˈhægəl/  to try to persuade someone to reduce the price of something by arguing with them about what it is worth:
examples: ▪ If you go to a street market, you’d better be prepared to haggle.
haggle over something
▪ The passenger haggled over the fare before she got into the taxi.
haggle with somebody
▪ My mother used to spend hours haggling with the market traders.

children.name: bargain with
children.definition: /ˈbɑːʳgɪn wɪð, ˈbɑːʳgən wɪð/  to try to persuade someone to reduce the price of something by discussing it with them:
examples: ▪ She bargained with the woman who was selling the plates and managed to get them for half the usual price.

children.name: beat sb down
children.definition: beat somebody down/ˌbiːt somebody ˈdaʊn/  to persuade someone to reduce the price of something by arguing with them about it:
examples: beat somebody down to $50/£20 etc
▪ The owners originally wanted $1000 for the horse, but George managed to beat them down to $850.
beat somebody down
▪ I beat him down and got the bracelet for $2.
